captions.text:
Compact SUVs seem to be the latest trend in
car design. They make sense, you get a lot

of the benefits of a supermini yet bags more
practicality! This is the Renault Captur,

which is essentially a larger Clio - and that
went down well in the CarBuyer office aside
from a few tiny complaints.

The Captur has an increased ride height and
is slightly longer than the Clio yet features

the same attractive styling features including
the slimming side glossy detailing and a different

bumper design incorporating daytime running
LEDs.

Those larger dimensions also mean extra practicality
as I promised at the beginning. The boot is

not only bigger than the Clio, it's also slightly
larger than in the Peugeot 2008 crossover,

which is handy if you have lots of shopping
bags or luggage. You can fold the seats on

a 60:40 split or with the seats up the entire
2nd row can be moved with this handle to give
more room in this already large boot.

Although this will impact on passenger space,
not an issue for 5 foot 4 and a half me, but

6 footers might have something to say about
it. Move the seats back individually and regain
your leg room, head room is very good as well.

While we're on the subject of seats, there
is so much adjustment in the driver's seat

and steering wheel that no matter whether
you are really tall or really not tall you

will find a comfortable driving position,
we are not ready for that just yet though,

que pan of dash so I can talk to you about
spec!

The same smart dash that appears in the Clio
is also found in the Captur and spec is very

generous. Even the entry-level model comes
with electric windows, cruise control, hill
start assist and 16" alloy wheels.

But before we drive off, let me show you some
of the Captur's clever storage...

It's a very easy car to drive because visibility
is good and the increased ride height gives

a more commanding view of the road so you
can work your way through traffic without

any dramas. This is aided further by the light
pedals and slick gearbox.

Engine choice is between two petrols and one
diesel, however the most economical is the

1.5-litre diesel which returns an impressive
76 miles to the gallon and emits less than

100 g/km of CO2. All cars come with an Eco
button on the dashboard, too, which limits

engine power and improves fuel economy by
10% - very handy for driving around town.

Sadly that brings me on to its negative points!
One of the reasons it is so good on fuel is

because it only comes in 2 wheel drive. So
it's a bit of a cheat to call it a compact

SUV really, 4 wheel drive would increase its
capabilities and keep it line with its competition

- like the Nissan Juke and Vauxhall Mokka.
It's also not that much fun to drive and it
is quite a bit more expensive than the Clio.

However it is still one of the best-value
options in its class and comes with loads

of equipment as standard. What's more, the
low running costs and decent practicality

all help to be a serious contender in the
compact SUV market.
